 98% (as you indicate) may support it (or may not), but apparently a sizeable portion of gay people at least don't consider it as important as other issues.

 
 Certainly gay rights is not the most important issue to all gay people, maybe not even half of gay people; they consider all of the issues just like anyone else would. But the number you've provided (and I did verify this) indicates an unimaginable impact of this issue on the gay community.
 
 It would not be unreasonable to assume that if gay rights were never an issue, the gay vote would have been split in the same fashion as the rest of the nation (51% Bush, 48% Kerry). But even if we assume that it would be split 50/50, we see a 54% increase in Kerry supporters simply because of this one issue. To put that in perspective, you have to imagine some issue that is so big that it caused over half of all Bush supporters to change their votes to Kerry. That is one incredible issue.
 
 And also keep in mind that Kerry didn't even support same-sex marriage; he just supported civil unions. In fact, he and Edwards went out of their ways to state that they do not support same-sex marriage. That just doesn't show the sort of commitment to gay rights that I was hoping he had, and I'm sure others felt the same way (though I voted for Kerry anyway, of course).
 
 So yes, it's true that gay people don't vote based only on gay rights, but the issue is incredibly important to most of them; even the 23% that voted Bush had a really tough time doing it. To say otherwise just isn't true.
